I saw a bus stop in front
of a large
crowd - the bus already
than full.
my amazement
every single one of the crowd got in.
seat was taken and each
sitter sitting bolt upright while in front of him between his
and the back of the seat ahead stood as many as could squeeze in. The
aisle was packed solid.
A bus designed for sixteen was
carrying not
less than sixty and no doubt after six months of such overloading the
operators will notify the German manufacturers that the busses have
are no good and they won't meet the next maturing payments.
rules, etc.
were not for
the foreign management.
airplane has a safe loading
capacity which is certified in the case of American planes by the
Department of Commerce, Aeronautics Division.
Every passenger
cargo is weighed.
Instructions not to overload are exact
uncompromising.
pilot checks cargo and his
weight report and re-
take off if the gross weight
is over
the safe limit.
who used to fly for Chiang Kai-shek tells
an amusing
had orders to fly his
Ford on a long trip over bad country
so he decided to take plenty of gas and had to cut
down his passenger
list to six.
Knowing the inclination of
the Chinese to overload he
took great pains to explain to the No. 1, who was a Secretary of Chiang
Kai-shek's,
that there could only be six
passengers.
Harry said he
made sure
that the instruction
was indubitably clear.
So forceful
he made his order that the following morning he didn't "cruise his cabin"
until he had taxied down to the end of the field.
Then he looked around
and there were seven passengers.
He was so mad that he didn't trust
himself to speak so he walked through the cabin and got outside to cool
the No. l followed and blandly asked if anything was
Harry said "Didn't I tell you only six passengers?"
No. l said there were only six.
Whereupon
Harry counted seven but the No. 1
pointed to a big fat Buadha-looking placid oriental in the back seat
and said "Oh he isn't a passenger, h√®'s just a servant."
Another time an American pilot flying a large Government
owned plane was given a load of silver to carry.
The men who were
going with the shipment kept piling cases into
the cabin until the
overload and finally made them take all the cases out.
being no scales the pilot himself lifted each case, guessed its weight,
marked it down and set the case over to one side to be put in the plane.
Several times he
caught his traveling companions (who were very anxious
to load all the silver) slipping a case which he hadn't "weighed" in
the other door of the plane.
After much explaining and no end of con-
fusion he thought he had the situation in hand.
Some silver was sent
back by the guards who brought it, the custodians were put on board
and the pilot took off.
The ship was overloaded and staggered off
near the end of the runway, the tail hit a pile of rocks,
damaging
washing away the
tail-skid and nearly wrecking
ta11 sur with the airplane vibrating badly and sliding around the
Then with
sky the pilot was afraid to make a landing with such a heavy load so
continued on to his destination too worried and busy to enjoy the
fright and discomfort of his passengers who had been responsible for
their predicament.
The pilot got down at Kweiyang all right and we
had dinner together that night with Missionaries.
When the Mission-
aries prayed before chow the pilot whispered to me that he was well
up on them in both fervor and amount of
praying that day. Later he
cheers for free silver, missionaries and opium took off in a cloud of
Debby and the girls are in Hongkong where I plan to join them
on Feb. 4th to spend Chinese New Year (The Nationalists call it Spring
Festival) because, in spite of the adoption by the National Government
of our calendar,
the Chinese still celebrate the old lunar New Year
there's no use trying to get anything accomplished during the
festivities.
As Ever,
